Example: if the setup has -2 degree to +10 degree collective pitch setup, the total range is 12 degrees. 50% of 12 degrees is 6 degrees, so this setting would correspond to +4 degree of pitch.

Name: H_RSC_THRCRV_75
Description: Sets the throttle output (HeliRSC servo) in percent for the throttle curve at 75% of full collective travel where he 0 percent collective is defined by H_COL_MIN and 100 percent collective is defined by H_COL_MAX.  Example: if the setup has -2 degree to +10 degree collective pitch setup, the total range is 12 degrees. 75% of 12 degrees is 9 degrees, so this setting would correspond to +7 degree of pitch.

Name: H_RSC_THRCRV_100
Description: Sets the throttle output (HeliRSC servo) in percent for the throttle curve at the minimum collective pitch position. The 100 percent collective is defined by H_COL_MAX.  Example: if the setup has -2 degree to +10 degree collective pitch setup, this setting would correspond to +10 degree of pitch.

Name: H_RSC_GOV_RANGE
Description: RPM range +/- governor rpm reference setting where governor is operational. If speed sensor fails or rpm falls outside of this range, the governor will disengage and return to throttle curve. Recommended range is 100

Name: H_RSC_AROT_PCT
Description: The throttle percentage sent to external governors, signaling to enable fast spool-up, when bailing out of an autorotation.  Set 0 to disable. If also using a tail rotor of type DDVP with external governor then this value must lie within the autorotation window of both governors.

Name: H_RSC_CLDWN_TIME
Description: Will provide a fast idle for engine cooldown by raising the Ground Idle speed setting by 50% for the number of seconds the timer is set for. A setting of zero disables the fast idle. This feature will only apply after the runup complete has been declared. This will not extend the time before ground idle is declared, which triggers engine shutdown for autonomous landings.

Name: H_RSC_GOV_COMP
Description: Adjusts the autothrottle governor torque compensator that determines how fast the governor will adjust the base torque reference to compensate for changes in density altitude. If RPM is low or high by more than 2-5 RPM, increase this setting by 1% at a time until the governor speed matches your RPM setting. Setting the compensator too high can result in surging and throttle "hunting". Do not make large adjustments at one time

Name: H_RSC_GOV_DROOP
Description: AutoThrottle governor droop response under load, normal settings of 0-50%. Higher value is quicker response to large speed changes due to load but may cause surging. Adjust this to be as aggressive as possible without getting surging or RPM over-run when the governor responds to large load changes on the rotor system

Name: H_RSC_GOV_FF
Description: Feedforward governor gain to throttle response during sudden loading/unloading of the rotor system. If RPM drops excessively during full collective climb with the droop response set correctly, increase the governor feedforward.

Name: H_RSC_GOV_RPM
Description: Main rotor RPM that governor maintains when engaged

Name: H_RSC_GOV_TORQUE
Description: Adjusts the engine's percentage of torque rise on autothrottle during ramp-up to governor speed. The torque rise will determine how fast the rotor speed will ramp up when rotor speed reaches 50% of the rotor RPM setting. The sequence of events engaging the governor is as follows: Throttle ramp time will engage the clutch and start the main rotor turning. The collective should be at flat pitch and the throttle curve set to provide at least 50% of normal RPM at flat pitch. The autothrottle torque limiter will automatically activate and start accelerating the main rotor. If the autothrottle consistently fails to accelerate the main rotor during ramp-in due to engine tune or other factors, then increase the torque limiter setting. NOTE: throttle ramp time and throttle curve should be tuned using RSC_MODE Throttle Curve before using RSC_MODE AutoThrottle

Name: IM_ACRO_COL_EXP
Description: Used to soften collective pitch inputs near center point in Acro mode.

Name: IM_STB_COL_1
Description: Helicopter's minimum collective pitch setting at zero collective stick input in Stabilize mode.  Set this as a percent of collective range given by H_COL_MAX minus H_COL_MIN.

Name: IM_STB_COL_2
Description: Helicopter's collective pitch setting at mid-low (40%) collective stick input in Stabilize mode. Set this as a percent of collective range given by H_COL_MAX minus H_COL_MIN.

Name: IM_STB_COL_3
Description: Helicopter's collective pitch setting at mid-high (60%) collective stick input in Stabilize mode. Set this as a percent of collective range given by H_COL_MAX minus H_COL_MIN.

Name: IM_STB_COL_4
Description: Helicopter's maximum collective pitch setting at full collective stick input in Stabilize mode. Set this as a percent of collective range given by H_COL_MAX minus H_COL_MIN.

Name: INS_GYROFFS_X
Description: Gyro sensor offsets of X axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

Name: INS_GYROFFS_Y
Description: Gyro sensor offsets of Y axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

Name: INS_GYROFFS_Z
Description: Gyro sensor offsets of Z axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

Name: INS_GYR2OFFS_X
Description: Gyro2 sensor offsets of X axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

Name: INS_GYR2OFFS_Y
Description: Gyro2 sensor offsets of Y axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

Name: INS_GYR2OFFS_Z
Description: Gyro2 sensor offsets of Z axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

Name: INS_GYR3OFFS_X
Description: Gyro3 sensor offsets of X axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

Name: INS_GYR3OFFS_Y
Description: Gyro3 sensor offsets of Y axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

Name: INS_GYR3OFFS_Z
Description: Gyro3 sensor offsets of Z axis. This is setup on each boot during gyro calibrations

Name: INS_ACCSCAL_X
Description: Accelerometer scaling of X axis.  Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

Name: INS_ACCSCAL_Y
Description: Accelerometer scaling of Y axis  Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

Name: INS_ACCSCAL_Z
Description: Accelerometer scaling of Z axis  Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

Name: INS_ACCOFFS_X
Description: Accelerometer offsets of X axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

Name: INS_ACCOFFS_Y
Description: Accelerometer offsets of Y axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

Name: INS_ACCOFFS_Z
Description: Accelerometer offsets of Z axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

Name: INS_ACC2SCAL_X
Description: Accelerometer2 scaling of X axis.  Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

Name: INS_ACC2SCAL_Y
Description: Accelerometer2 scaling of Y axis  Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

Name: INS_ACC2SCAL_Z
Description: Accelerometer2 scaling of Z axis  Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

Name: INS_ACC2OFFS_X
Description: Accelerometer2 offsets of X axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

Name: INS_ACC2OFFS_Y
Description: Accelerometer2 offsets of Y axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

Name: INS_ACC2OFFS_Z
Description: Accelerometer2 offsets of Z axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

Name: INS_ACC3SCAL_X
Description: Accelerometer3 scaling of X axis.  Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

Name: INS_ACC3SCAL_Y
Description: Accelerometer3 scaling of Y axis  Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

Name: INS_ACC3SCAL_Z
Description: Accelerometer3 scaling of Z axis  Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

Name: INS_ACC3OFFS_X
Description: Accelerometer3 offsets of X axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

Name: INS_ACC3OFFS_Y
Description: Accelerometer3 offsets of Y axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

Name: INS_ACC3OFFS_Z
Description: Accelerometer3 offsets of Z axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

Name: INS_GYRO_FILTER
Description: Filter cutoff frequency for gyroscopes. This can be set to a lower value to try to cope with very high vibration levels in aircraft. A value of zero means no filtering (not recommended!)

Name: INS_ACCEL_FILTER
Description: Filter cutoff frequency for accelerometers. This can be set to a lower value to try to cope with very high vibration levels in aircraft. A value of zero means no filtering (not recommended!)

Name: INS_USE
Description: Use first IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates

Name: INS_USE2
Description: Use second IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates

Name: INS_USE3
Description: Use third IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates

Name: INS_STILL_THRESH
Description: Threshold to tolerate vibration to determine if vehicle is motionless. This depends on the frame type and if there is a constant vibration due to motors before launch or after landing. Total motionless is about 0.05. Suggested values: Planes/rover use 0.1, multirotors use 1, tradHeli uses 5

Name: INS_GYR_CAL
Description: Conrols when automatic gyro calibration is performed

Name: INS_TRIM_OPTION
Description: Specifies how the accel cal routine determines the trims

Name: INS_ACC_BODYFIX
Description: The body-fixed accelerometer to be used for trim calculation

Name: INS_POS1_X
Description: X position of the first IMU Accelerometer in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

Name: INS_POS1_Y
Description: Y position of the first IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

Name: INS_POS1_Z
Description: Z position of the first IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

Name: INS_POS2_X
Description: X position of the second IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

Name: INS_POS2_Y
Description: Y position of the second IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

Name: INS_POS2_Z
Description: Z position of the second IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

Name: INS_POS3_X
Description: X position of the third IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

Name: INS_POS3_Y
Description: Y position of the third IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

Name: INS_POS3_Z
Description: Z position of the third IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

Name: INS_GYR_ID
Description: Gyro sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

Name: INS_GYR2_ID
Description: Gyro2 sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

Name: INS_GYR3_ID
Description: Gyro3 sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

Name: INS_ACC_ID
Description: Accelerometer sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

Name: INS_ACC2_ID
Description: Accelerometer2 sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

Name: INS_ACC3_ID
Description: Accelerometer3 sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

Name: INS_FAST_SAMPLE
Description: Mask of IMUs to enable fast sampling on, if available

Name: INS_ENABLE_MASK
Description: Bitmask of IMUs to enable. It can be used to prevent startup of specific detected IMUs

Name: INS_GYRO_RATE
Description: Gyro rate for IMUs with fast sampling enabled. The gyro rate is the sample rate at which the IMU filters operate and needs to be at least double the maximum filter frequency. If the sensor does not support the selected rate the next highest supported rate will be used. For IMUs which do not support fast sampling this setting is ignored and the default gyro rate of 1Khz is used.

Name: INS_ACC1_CALTEMP
Description: Temperature that the 1st accelerometer was calibrated at

Name: INS_GYR1_CALTEMP
Description: Temperature that the 1st gyroscope was calibrated at

Name: INS_ACC2_CALTEMP
Description: Temperature that the 2nd accelerometer was calibrated at

Name: INS_GYR2_CALTEMP
Description: Temperature that the 2nd gyroscope was calibrated at

Name: INS_ACC3_CALTEMP
Description: Temperature that the 3rd accelerometer was calibrated at

Name: INS_GYR3_CALTEMP
Description: Temperature that the 3rd gyroscope was calibrated at

Name: INS_TCAL_OPTIONS
Description: This enables optional temperature calibration features. Setting PersistParams will save the accelerometer and temperature calibration parameters in the bootloader sector on the next update of the bootloader.

Name: INS_HNTCH_ENABLE
Description: Harmonic Notch Filter enable

Name: INS_HNTCH_FREQ
Description: Harmonic Notch Filter base center frequency in Hz. This should be set at most half the backend gyro rate (which is typically 1Khz). For helicopters using RPM sensor to dynamically set the notch frequency, use this parameter to provide a lower limit to the dynamic notch filter.  Recommend setting it to half the operating rotor speed in Hz.

Name: INS_HNTCH_BW
Description: Harmonic Notch Filter bandwidth in Hz. This is typically set to half the base frequency. The ratio of base frequency to bandwidth determines the notch quality factor and is fixed across harmonics.

Name: INS_HNTCH_ATT
Description: Harmonic Notch Filter attenuation in dB. Values greater than 40dB will typically produce a hard notch rather than a modest attenuation of motor noise.

Name: INS_HNTCH_HMNCS
Description: Bitmask of harmonic frequencies to apply Harmonic Notch Filter to. This option takes effect on the next reboot.

Name: INS_HNTCH_REF
Description: A reference value of zero disables dynamic updates on the Harmonic Notch Filter and a positive value enables dynamic updates on the Harmonic Notch Filter.  For throttle-based scaling, this parameter is the reference value associated with the specified frequency to facilitate frequency scaling of the Harmonic Notch Filter. For RPM and ESC telemetry based tracking, this parameter is set to 1 to enable the Harmonic Notch Filter using the RPM sensor or ESC telemetry set to measure rotor speed.  The sensor data is converted to Hz automatically for use in the Harmonic Notch Filter.  This reference value may also be used to scale the sensor data, if required.  For example, rpm sensor data is required to measure heli motor RPM. Therefore the reference value can be used to scale the RPM sensor to the rotor RPM.

Name: INS_HNTCH_MODE
Description: Harmonic Notch Filter dynamic frequency tracking mode. Dynamic updates can be throttle, RPM sensor, ESC telemetry or dynamic FFT based. Throttle-based updates should only be used with multicopters.

Name: INS_HNTCH_OPTS
Description: Harmonic Notch Filter options. Double-notches can provide deeper attenuation across a wider bandwidth than single notches and are suitable for larger aircraft. Dynamic harmonics attaches a harmonic notch to each detected noise frequency instead of simply being multiples of the base frequency, in the case of FFT it will attach notches to each of three detected noise peaks, in the case of ESC it will attach notches to each of four motor RPM values. Loop rate update changes the notch center frequency at the scheduler loop rate rather than at the default of 200Hz.

Name: INS_LOG_BAT_CNT
Description: Number of samples to take when logging streams of IMU sensor readings.  Will be rounded down to a multiple of 32. This option takes effect on the next reboot.

Name: INS_LOG_BAT_MASK
Description: Bitmap of which IMUs to log batch data for. This option takes effect on the next reboot.

Name: INS_LOG_BAT_OPT
Description: Options for the BatchSampler. Post-filter and sensor-rate logging cannot be used at the same time.

Name: INS_LOG_BAT_LGIN
Description: Interval between pushing samples to the AP_Logger log

Name: INS_LOG_BAT_LGCT
Description: Number of samples to push to count every INS_LOG_BAT_LGIN

Name: INS_NOTCH_ENABLE
Description: Harmonic Notch Filter enable

Name: INS_NOTCH_FREQ
Description: Harmonic Notch Filter base center frequency in Hz. This should be set at most half the backend gyro rate (which is typically 1Khz). For helicopters using RPM sensor to dynamically set the notch frequency, use this parameter to provide a lower limit to the dynamic notch filter.  Recommend setting it to half the operating rotor speed in Hz.

Name: INS_NOTCH_BW
Description: Harmonic Notch Filter bandwidth in Hz. This is typically set to half the base frequency. The ratio of base frequency to bandwidth determines the notch quality factor and is fixed across harmonics.

Name: INS_NOTCH_ATT
Description: Harmonic Notch Filter attenuation in dB. Values greater than 40dB will typically produce a hard notch rather than a modest attenuation of motor noise.

Name: INS_NOTCH_HMNCS
Description: Bitmask of harmonic frequencies to apply Harmonic Notch Filter to. This option takes effect on the next reboot.

Name: INS_NOTCH_REF
Description: A reference value of zero disables dynamic updates on the Harmonic Notch Filter and a positive value enables dynamic updates on the Harmonic Notch Filter.  For throttle-based scaling, this parameter is the reference value associated with the specified frequency to facilitate frequency scaling of the Harmonic Notch Filter. For RPM and ESC telemetry based tracking, this parameter is set to 1 to enable the Harmonic Notch Filter using the RPM sensor or ESC telemetry set to measure rotor speed.  The sensor data is converted to Hz automatically for use in the Harmonic Notch Filter.  This reference value may also be used to scale the sensor data, if required.  For example, rpm sensor data is required to measure heli motor RPM. Therefore the reference value can be used to scale the RPM sensor to the rotor RPM.

Name: INS_NOTCH_MODE
Description: Harmonic Notch Filter dynamic frequency tracking mode. Dynamic updates can be throttle, RPM sensor, ESC telemetry or dynamic FFT based. Throttle-based updates should only be used with multicopters.

Name: INS_NOTCH_OPTS
Description: Harmonic Notch Filter options. Double-notches can provide deeper attenuation across a wider bandwidth than single notches and are suitable for larger aircraft. Dynamic harmonics attaches a harmonic notch to each detected noise frequency instead of simply being multiples of the base frequency, in the case of FFT it will attach notches to each of three detected noise peaks, in the case of ESC it will attach notches to each of four motor RPM values. Loop rate update changes the notch center frequency at the scheduler loop rate rather than at the default of 200Hz.

Name: INS_TCAL1_ENABLE
Description: Enable the use of temperature calibration parameters for this IMU. For automatic learning set to 2 and also set the INS_TCALn_TMAX to the target temperature, then reboot

Name: LGR_ENABLE
Description: Enable landing gear control

Name: LGR_STARTUP
Description: Landing Gear Startup behaviour control

Name: LGR_DEPLOY_PIN
Description: Pin number to use for detection of gear deployment. If set to -1 feedback is disabled.

Name: LGR_DEPLOY_POL
Description: Polarity for feedback pin. If this is 1 then the pin should be high when gear are deployed. If set to 0 then then deployed gear level is low.

Name: LGR_WOW_PIN
Description: Pin number to use for feedback of weight on wheels condition. If set to -1 feedback is disabled.

Name: LGR_WOW_POL
Description: Polarity for feedback pin. If this is 1 then the pin should be high when there is weight on wheels. If set to 0 then then weight on wheels level is low.

Name: LGR_DEPLOY_ALT
Description: Altitude where the landing gear will be deployed. This should be lower than the RETRACT_ALT. If zero then altitude is not used for deploying landing gear. Only applies when vehicle is armed.

Name: LGR_RETRACT_ALT
Description: Altitude where the landing gear will be retracted. This should be higher than the DEPLOY_ALT. If zero then altitude is not used for retracting landing gear. Only applies when vehicle is armed.

Name: LGR_OPTIONS
Description: Options to retract or deploy landing gear in Auto or Guided mode

Name: LOG_BACKEND_TYPE
Description: Bitmap of what Logger backend types to enable. Block-based logging is available on SITL and boards with dataflash chips. Multiple backends can be selected.

Name: LOG_FILE_BUFSIZE
Description: The File and Block backends use a buffer to store data before writing to the block device.  Raising this value may reduce "gaps" in your SD card logging.  This buffer size may be reduced depending on available memory.  PixHawk requires at least 4 kilobytes.  Maximum value available here is 64 kilobytes.

Name: LOG_DISARMED
Description: If LOG_DISARMED is set to 1 then logging will be enabled while disarmed. This can make for very large logfiles but can help a lot when tracking down startup issues

Name: LOG_REPLAY
Description: If LOG_REPLAY is set to 1 then the EKF2 state estimator will log detailed information needed for diagnosing problems with the Kalman filter. It is suggested that you also raise LOG_FILE_BUFSIZE to give more buffer space for logging and use a high quality microSD card to ensure no sensor data is lost

Name: LOG_FILE_DSRMROT
Description: When set, the current log file is closed when the vehicle is disarmed.  If LOG_DISARMED is set then a fresh log will be opened. Applies to the File and Block logging backends.

Name: LOG_MAV_BUFSIZE
Description: Maximum amount of memory to allocate to AP_Logger-over-mavlink

Name: LOG_FILE_TIMEOUT
Description: This controls the amount of time before failing writes to a log file cause the file to be closed and logging stopped.

Name: LOG_FILE_MB_FREE
Description: Set this such that the free space is larger than your largest typical flight log

Name: LOG_FILE_RATEMAX
Description: This sets the maximum rate that streaming log messages will be logged to the file backend. A value of zero means that rate limiting is disabled.

Name: LOG_MAV_RATEMAX
Description: This sets the maximum rate that streaming log messages will be logged to the mavlink backend. A value of zero means that rate limiting is disabled.

Name: LOG_BLK_RATEMAX
Description: This sets the maximum rate that streaming log messages will be logged to the mavlink backend. A value of zero means that rate limiting is disabled.

Name: LOIT_ANG_MAX
Description: Loiter maximum pilot requested lean angle. Set to zero for 2/3 of PSC_ANGLE_MAX/ANGLE_MAX. The maximum vehicle lean angle is still limited by PSC_ANGLE_MAX/ANGLE_MAX

Name: LOIT_SPEED
Description: Defines the maximum speed in cm/s which the aircraft will travel horizontally while in loiter mode

Name: LOIT_ACC_MAX
Description: Loiter maximum correction acceleration in cm/s/s.  Higher values cause the copter to correct position errors more aggressively.

Name: LOIT_BRK_ACCEL
Description: Loiter braking acceleration in cm/s/s. Higher values stop the copter more quickly when the stick is centered.

Name: LOIT_BRK_JERK
Description: Loiter braking jerk in cm/s/s/s. Higher values will remove braking faster if the pilot moves the sticks during a braking maneuver.

Name: LOIT_BRK_DELAY
Description: Loiter brake start delay (in seconds)

Name: MIS_TOTAL
Description: The number of mission mission items that has been loaded by the ground station. Do not change this manually.

Name: MIS_RESTART
Description: Controls mission starting point when entering Auto mode (either restart from beginning of mission or resume from last command run)

Name: MIS_OPTIONS
Description: Bitmask of what options to use in missions.

Name: MNT_TYPE
Description: Mount Type (None, Servo or MAVLink)

Name: MNT_DEFLT_MODE
Description: Mount default operating mode on startup and after control is returned from autopilot

Name: MNT_RETRACT_X
Description: Mount roll angle when in retracted position

Name: MNT_RETRACT_Y
Description: Mount tilt/pitch angle when in retracted position

Name: MNT_RETRACT_Z
Description: Mount yaw/pan angle when in retracted position

Name: MNT_NEUTRAL_X
Description: Mount roll angle when in neutral position

Name: MNT_NEUTRAL_Y
Description: Mount tilt/pitch angle when in neutral position

Name: MNT_NEUTRAL_Z
Description: Mount pan/yaw angle when in neutral position

Name: MNT_STAB_ROLL
Description: enable roll stabilisation relative to Earth

Name: MNT_STAB_TILT
Description: enable tilt/pitch stabilisation relative to Earth

Name: MNT_STAB_PAN
Description: enable pan/yaw stabilisation relative to Earth

Name: MNT_RC_IN_ROLL
Description: 0 for none, any other for the RC channel to be used to control roll movements

Name: MNT_ANGMIN_ROL
Description: Minimum physical roll angular position of mount.

Name: MNT_ANGMAX_ROL
Description: Maximum physical roll angular position of the mount

Name: MNT_RC_IN_TILT
Description: 0 for none, any other for the RC channel to be used to control tilt (pitch) movements

Name: MNT_ANGMIN_TIL
Description: Minimum physical tilt (pitch) angular position of mount.

Name: MNT_ANGMAX_TIL
Description: Maximum physical tilt (pitch) angular position of the mount

Name: MNT_RC_IN_PAN
Description: 0 for none, any other for the RC channel to be used to control pan (yaw) movements

Name: MNT_ANGMIN_PAN
Description: Minimum physical pan (yaw) angular position of mount.

Name: MNT_ANGMAX_PAN
Description: Maximum physical pan (yaw) angular position of the mount

Name: MNT_JSTICK_SPD
Description: 0 for position control, small for low speeds, 100 for max speed. A good general value is 10 which gives a movement speed of 3 degrees per second.

Name: MNT_LEAD_RLL
Description: Causes the servo angle output to lead the current angle of the vehicle by some amount of time based on current angular rate, compensating for servo delay. Increase until the servo is responsive but doesn't overshoot. Does nothing with pan stabilization enabled.

Name: MNT_LEAD_PTCH
Description: Causes the servo angle output to lead the current angle of the vehicle by some amount of time based on current angular rate. Increase until the servo is responsive but doesn't overshoot. Does nothing with pan stabilization enabled.

Name: MNT2_DEFLT_MODE
Description: Mount default operating mode on startup and after control is returned from autopilot

Name: MNT2_RETRACT_X
Description: Mount2 roll angle when in retracted position

Name: MNT2_RETRACT_Y
Description: Mount2 tilt/pitch angle when in retracted position

Name: MNT2_RETRACT_Z
Description: Mount2 yaw/pan angle when in retracted position

Name: MNT2_NEUTRAL_X
Description: Mount2 roll angle when in neutral position

Name: MNT2_NEUTRAL_Y
Description: Mount2 tilt/pitch angle when in neutral position

Name: MNT2_NEUTRAL_Z
Description: Mount2 pan/yaw angle when in neutral position

Name: MNT2_STAB_ROLL
Description: enable roll stabilisation relative to Earth

Name: MNT2_STAB_TILT
Description: enable tilt/pitch stabilisation relative to Earth

Name: MNT2_STAB_PAN
Description: enable pan/yaw stabilisation relative to Earth

Name: MNT2_RC_IN_ROLL
Description: 0 for none, any other for the RC channel to be used to control roll movements

Name: MNT2_ANGMIN_ROL
Description: Mount2's minimum physical roll angular position

Name: MNT2_ANGMAX_ROL
Description: Mount2's maximum physical roll angular position

Name: MNT2_RC_IN_TILT
Description: 0 for none, any other for the RC channel to be used to control tilt (pitch) movements

Name: MNT2_ANGMIN_TIL
Description: Mount2's minimum physical tilt (pitch) angular position

Name: MNT2_ANGMAX_TIL
Description: Mount2's maximum physical tilt (pitch) angular position

Name: MNT2_RC_IN_PAN
Description: 0 for none, any other for the RC channel to be used to control pan (yaw) movements

Name: MNT2_ANGMIN_PAN
Description: Mount2's minimum physical pan (yaw) angular position

Name: MNT2_ANGMAX_PAN
Description: MOunt2's maximum physical pan (yaw) angular position

Name: MNT2_LEAD_RLL
Description: Causes the servo angle output to lead the current angle of the vehicle by some amount of time based on current angular rate, compensating for servo delay. Increase until the servo is responsive but doesn't overshoot. Does nothing with pan stabilization enabled.

Name: MNT2_LEAD_PTCH
Description: Causes the servo angle output to lead the current angle of the vehicle by some amount of time based on current angular rate. Increase until the servo is responsive but doesn't overshoot. Does nothing with pan stabilization enabled.

Name: MNT2_TYPE
Description: Mount Type (None, Servo or MAVLink)

Name: MOT_YAW_HEADROOM
Description: Yaw control is given at least this pwm in microseconds range

Name: MOT_THST_EXPO
Description: Motor thrust curve exponent (0.0 for linear to 1.0 for second order curve)

Name: MOT_SPIN_MAX
Description: Point at which the thrust saturates expressed as a number from 0 to 1 in the entire output range

Name: MOT_BAT_VOLT_MAX
Description: Battery voltage compensation maximum voltage (voltage above this will have no additional scaling effect on thrust).  Recommend 4.2 * cell count, 0 = Disabled

Name: MOT_BAT_VOLT_MIN
Description: Battery voltage compensation minimum voltage (voltage below this will have no additional scaling effect on thrust).  Recommend 3.3 * cell count, 0 = Disabled

Name: MOT_BAT_CURR_MAX
Description: Maximum current over which maximum throttle is limited (0 = Disabled)

Name: MOT_PWM_TYPE
Description: This selects the output PWM type, allowing for normal PWM continuous output, OneShot, brushed or DShot motor output

Name: MOT_PWM_MIN
Description: This sets the min PWM output value in microseconds that will ever be output to the motors

Name: MOT_PWM_MAX
Description: This sets the max PWM value in microseconds that will ever be output to the motors

Name: MOT_SPIN_MIN
Description: Point at which the thrust starts expressed as a number from 0 to 1 in the entire output range.  Should be higher than MOT_SPIN_ARM.

Name: MOT_SPIN_ARM
Description: Point at which the motors start to spin expressed as a number from 0 to 1 in the entire output range.  Should be lower than MOT_SPIN_MIN.

Name: MOT_BAT_CURR_TC
Description: Time constant used to limit the maximum current

Name: MOT_THST_HOVER
Description: Motor thrust needed to hover expressed as a number from 0 to 1

Name: MOT_HOVER_LEARN
Description: Enable/Disable automatic learning of hover throttle

Name: MOT_SAFE_DISARM
Description: Disables motor PWM output when disarmed

Name: MOT_YAW_SV_ANGLE
Description: Yaw servo's maximum lean angle

Name: MOT_SPOOL_TIME
Description: Time in seconds to spool up the motors from zero to min throttle.

Name: MOT_BOOST_SCALE
Description: Booster motor output scaling factor vs main throttle.  The output to the BoostThrottle servo will be the main throttle times this scaling factor. A higher scaling factor will put more of the load on the booster motor. A value of 1 will set the BoostThrottle equal to the main throttle.

Name: MOT_BAT_IDX
Description: Which battery monitor should be used for doing compensation

Name: MOT_SLEW_UP_TIME
Description: Time in seconds to slew output from zero to full. This is used to limit the rate at which output can change. Range is constrained between 0 and 0.5.

Name: MOT_SLEW_DN_TIME
Description: Time in seconds to slew output from full to zero. This is used to limit the rate at which output can change.  Range is constrained between 0 and 0.5.

Name: MOT_SAFE_TIME
Description: Time taken to disable and enable the motor PWM output when disarmed and armed.

Name: MSP_OSD_NCELLS
Description: Used for average cell voltage calculation

Name: MSP_OPTIONS
Description: A bitmask to set some MSP specific options

Name: NTF_LED_BRIGHT
Description: Select the RGB LED brightness level. When USB is connected brightness will never be higher than low regardless of the setting.

Name: NTF_BUZZ_TYPES
Description: Controls what types of Buzzer will be enabled

Name: NTF_LED_OVERRIDE
Description: Specifies the source for the colours and brightness for the LED.  OutbackChallenge conforms to the MedicalExpress (https://uavchallenge.org/medical-express/) rules, essentially "Green" is disarmed (safe-to-approach), "Red" is armed (not safe-to-approach). Traffic light is a simplified color set, red when armed, yellow when the safety switch is not surpressing outputs (but disarmed), and green when outputs are surpressed and disarmed, the LED will blink faster if disarmed and failing arming checks.

Name: NTF_DISPLAY_TYPE
Description: This sets up the type of on-board I2C display. Disabled by default.

Name: NTF_OREO_THEME
Description: Enable/Disable Solo Oreo LED driver, 0 to disable, 1 for Aircraft theme, 2 for Rover theme

Name: NTF_BUZZ_PIN
Description: Enables to connect active buzzer to arbitrary pin. Requires 3-pin buzzer or additional MOSFET!

Name: NTF_LED_TYPES
Description: Controls what types of LEDs will be enabled

Name: NTF_BUZZ_ON_LVL
Description: Specifies pin level that indicates buzzer should play

Name: NTF_BUZZ_VOLUME
Description: Control the volume of the buzzer

Name: NTF_LED_LEN
Description: The number of Serial LED's to use for notifications (NeoPixel's and ProfiLED)

Name: OA_TYPE
Description: Enabled/disable path planning around obstacles

Name: OA_MARGIN_MAX
Description: Object Avoidance will ignore objects more than this many meters from vehicle

Name: OA_OPTIONS
Description: Bitmask which will govern vehicles behaviour while recovering from Obstacle Avoidance (i.e Avoidance is turned off after the path ahead is clear).

Name: OA_BR_LOOKAHEAD
Description: Object Avoidance will look this many meters ahead of vehicle

Name: OA_BR_CONT_RATIO
Description: BendyRuler will avoid changing bearing unless ratio of previous margin from obstacle (or fence) to present calculated margin is atleast this much.

Name: OA_BR_CONT_ANGLE
Description: BendyRuler will resist changing current bearing if the change in bearing is over this angle

Name: OA_BR_TYPE
Description: BendyRuler will search for clear path along the direction defined by this parameter

Name: OA_DB_SIZE
Description: OADatabase maximum number of points. Set to 0 to disable the OA Database. Larger means more points but is more cpu intensive to process

Name: OA_DB_EXPIRE
Description: OADatabase item timeout. The time an item will linger without any updates before it expires. Zero means never expires which is useful for a sent-once static environment but terrible for dynamic ones.

Name: OA_DB_QUEUE_SIZE
Description: OADatabase queue maximum number of points. This in an input buffer size. Larger means it can handle larger bursts of incoming data points to filter into the database. No impact on cpu, only RAM. Recommend larger for faster datalinks or for sensors that generate a lot of data.

Name: OA_DB_OUTPUT
Description: OADatabase output level to configure which database objects are sent to the ground station. All data is always available internally for avoidance algorithms.

Name: OA_DB_BEAM_WIDTH
Description: Beam width of incoming lidar data

Name: OA_DB_RADIUS_MIN
Description: Minimum radius of objects held in database

Name: OA_DB_DIST_MAX
Description: Maximum distance of objects held in database.  Set to zero to disable the limits

Name: OA_DB_ALT_MIN
Description: OADatabase will reject obstacle's if vehicle's altitude above home is below this parameter, in a 3 meter radius around home. Set 0 to disable this feature.

Name: OSD_TYPE
Description: OSD type. TXONLY makes the OSD parameter selection available to other modules even if there is no native OSD support on the board, for instance CRSF.

Name: OSD_CHAN
Description: This sets the channel used to switch different OSD screens.

Name: OSD_SW_METHOD
Description: This sets the method used to switch different OSD screens.

Name: OSD_OPTIONS
Description: This sets options that change the display

Name: OSD_FONT
Description: This sets which OSD font to use. It is an integer from 0 to the number of fonts available

Name: OSD_V_OFFSET
Description: Sets vertical offset of the osd inside image

Name: OSD_H_OFFSET
Description: Sets horizontal offset of the osd inside image

Name: OSD_W_RSSI
Description: Set level at which RSSI item will flash

Name: OSD_W_NSAT
Description: Set level at which NSAT item will flash

Name: OSD_W_BATVOLT
Description: Set level at which BAT_VOLT item will flash

Name: OSD_UNITS
Description: Sets the units to use in displaying items

Name: OSD_MSG_TIME
Description: Sets message duration seconds

Name: OSD_ARM_SCR
Description: Screen to be shown on Arm event. Zero to disable the feature.

Name: OSD_DSARM_SCR
Description: Screen to be shown on disarm event. Zero to disable the feature.

Name: OSD_FS_SCR
Description: Screen to be shown on failsafe event. Zero to disable the feature.

Name: OSD_BTN_DELAY
Description: Debounce time in ms for stick commanded parameter navigation.

Name: OSD_W_TERR
Description: Set level below which TER_HGT item will flash. -1 disables.

Name: OSD_W_AVGCELLV
Description: Set level at which AVGCELLV item will flash

Name: OSD_CELL_COUNT
Description: Used for average cell voltage display. -1 disables, 0 uses cell count autodetection for well charged LIPO/LIION batteries at connection, other values manually select cell count used.

Name: OSD_W_RESTVOLT
Description: Set level at which RESTVOLT item will flash

Name: OSD1_ENABLE
Description: Enable this screen

Name: OSD1_CHAN_MIN
Description: This sets the PWM lower limit for this screen

Name: OSD1_CHAN_MAX
Description: This sets the PWM upper limit for this screen

Name: OSD1_ALTITUDE_EN
Description: Enables display of altitude AGL

Name: OSD1_ALTITUDE_X
Description: Horizontal position on screen

Name: OSD1_ALTITUDE_Y
Description: Vertical position on screen

Name: OSD1_BAT_VOLT_EN
Description: Displays main battery voltage

Name: OSD1_BAT_VOLT_X
Description: Horizontal position on screen

Name: OSD1_BAT_VOLT_Y
Description: Vertical position on screen

Name: OSD1_RSSI_EN
Description: Displays RC signal strength

Name: OSD1_RSSI_X
Description: Horizontal position on screen

Name: OSD1_RSSI_Y
Description: Vertical position on screen

Name: PLND_ENABLED
Description: Precision Land enabled/disabled

Name: PLND_TYPE
Description: Precision Land Type

Name: PLND_YAW_ALIGN
Description: Yaw angle from body x-axis to sensor x-axis.

Name: PLND_LAND_OFS_X
Description: Desired landing position of the camera forward of the target in vehicle body frame

Name: PLND_LAND_OFS_Y
Description: desired landing position of the camera right of the target in vehicle body frame

Name: PLND_EST_TYPE
Description: Specifies the estimation method to be used

Name: PLND_ACC_P_NSE
Description: Kalman Filter Accelerometer Noise, higher values weight the input from the camera more, accels less

Name: PLND_CAM_POS_X
Description: X position of the camera in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin.

Name: PLND_CAM_POS_Y
Description: Y position of the camera in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin.

Name: PLND_CAM_POS_Z
Description: Z position of the camera in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin.

Name: PLND_BUS
Description: Precland sensor bus for I2C sensors.

Name: PLND_LAG
Description: Precision Landing sensor lag, to cope with variable landing_target latency

Name: PLND_XY_DIST_MAX
Description: The vehicle will not start descending if the landing target is detected and it is further than this many meters away. Set 0 to always descend.

Name: PLND_STRICT
Description: How strictly should the vehicle land on the target if target is lost

Name: PLND_RET_MAX
Description: PrecLand Maximum number of retires for a failed landing. Set to zero to disable landing retry.

Name: PLND_TIMEOUT
Description: Time for which vehicle continues descend even if target is lost. After this time period, vehicle will attemp a landing retry depending on PLND_STRICT parameter.

Name: PLND_RET_BEHAVE
Description: Prec Land will do the action selected by this parameter if a retry to a landing is needed

Name: PLND_ALT_MIN
Description: Vehicle will continue landing vertically even if target is lost below this height. This needs a rangefinder to work. Set to zero to disable this.

Name: PLND_ALT_MAX
Description: Vehicle will continue landing vertically until this height if target is not found. Below this height if landing target is not found, landing retry/failsafe might be attempted. This needs a rangefinder to work. Set to zero to disable this.

Name: PLND_OPTIONS
Description: Precision Landing Extra Options

Name: PRX_TYPE
Description: What type of proximity sensor is connected

Name: PRX_ORIENT
Description: Proximity sensor orientation

Name: PRX_YAW_CORR
Description: Proximity sensor yaw correction

Name: PRX_IGN_ANG1
Description: Proximity sensor ignore angle 1

Name: PRX_IGN_WID1
Description: Proximity sensor ignore width 1

Name: PRX_IGN_ANG2
Description: Proximity sensor ignore angle 2

Name: PRX_IGN_WID2
Description: Proximity sensor ignore width 2

Name: PRX_IGN_ANG3
Description: Proximity sensor ignore angle 3

Name: PRX_IGN_WID3
Description: Proximity sensor ignore width 3

Name: PRX_IGN_ANG4
Description: Proximity sensor ignore angle 4

Name: PRX_IGN_WID4
Description: Proximity sensor ignore width 4

Name: PRX_IGN_ANG5
Description: Proximity sensor ignore angle 5

Name: PRX_IGN_WID5
Description: Proximity sensor ignore width 5

Name: PRX_IGN_ANG6
Description: Proximity sensor ignore angle 6

Name: PRX_IGN_WID6
Description: Proximity sensor ignore width 6

Name: PRX_IGN_GND
Description: Ignore proximity data that is within 1 meter of the ground below the vehicle. This requires a downward facing rangefinder

Name: PRX_LOG_RAW
Description: Set this parameter to one if logging unfiltered(raw) distances from sensor should be enabled

Name: PRX_FILT
Description: Cutoff frequency for low pass filter applied to each face in the proximity boundary

Name: PRX_MIN
Description: Minimum expected range for Proximity Sensor. Setting this to 0 will set value to manufacturer reported range.

Name: PRX_MAX
Description: Maximum expected range for Proximity Sensor. Setting this to 0 will set value to manufacturer reported range.

Name: PSC_ACC_XY_FILT
Description: Lower values will slow the response of the navigation controller and reduce twitchiness

Name: PSC_POSZ_P
Description: Position (vertical) controller P gain.  Converts the difference between the desired altitude and actual altitude into a climb or descent rate which is passed to the throttle rate controller

Name: PSC_VELZ_P
Description: Velocity (vertical) controller P gain.  Converts the difference between desired vertical speed and actual speed into a desired acceleration that is passed to the throttle acceleration controller

Name: PSC_VELZ_I
Description: Velocity (vertical) controller I gain.  Corrects long-term difference in desired velocity to a target acceleration

Name: PSC_VELZ_IMAX
Description: Velocity (vertical) controller I gain maximum.  Constrains the target acceleration that the I gain will output

Name: PSC_VELZ_D
Description: Velocity (vertical) controller D gain.  Corrects short-term changes in velocity

Name: PSC_VELZ_FF
Description: Velocity (vertical) controller Feed Forward gain.  Produces an output that is proportional to the magnitude of the target

Name: PSC_VELZ_FLTE
Description: Velocity (vertical) error filter.  This filter (in Hz) is applied to the input for P and I terms

Name: PSC_VELZ_FLTD
Description: Velocity (vertical) input filter for D term.  This filter (in Hz) is applied to the input for D terms

Name: PSC_ACCZ_P
Description: Acceleration (vertical) controller P gain.  Converts the difference between desired vertical acceleration and actual acceleration into a motor output

Name: PSC_ACCZ_I
Description: Acceleration (vertical) controller I gain.  Corrects long-term difference in desired vertical acceleration and actual acceleration

Name: PSC_ACCZ_IMAX
Description: Acceleration (vertical) controller I gain maximum.  Constrains the maximum pwm that the I term will generate

Name: PSC_ACCZ_D
Description: Acceleration (vertical) controller D gain.  Compensates for short-term change in desired vertical acceleration vs actual acceleration

Name: PSC_ACCZ_FF
Description: Acceleration (vertical) controller feed forward

Name: PSC_ACCZ_FLTT
Description: Acceleration (vertical) controller target frequency in Hz

Name: PSC_ACCZ_FLTE
Description: Acceleration (vertical) controller error frequency in Hz

Name: PSC_ACCZ_FLTD
Description: Acceleration (vertical) controller derivative frequency in Hz

Name: PSC_ACCZ_SMAX
Description: Sets an upper limit on the slew rate produced by the combined P and D gains. If the amplitude of the control action produced by the rate feedback exceeds this value, then the D+P gain is reduced to respect the limit. This limits the amplitude of high frequency oscillations caused by an excessive gain. The limit should be set to no more than 25% of the actuators maximum slew rate to allow for load effects. Note: The gain will not be reduced to less than 10% of the nominal value. A value of zero will disable this feature.

Name: PSC_POSXY_P
Description: Position controller P gain.  Converts the distance (in the latitude direction) to the target location into a desired speed which is then passed to the loiter latitude rate controller

Name: PSC_VELXY_P
Description: Velocity (horizontal) P gain.  Converts the difference between desired and actual velocity to a target acceleration

Name: PSC_VELXY_I
Description: Velocity (horizontal) I gain.  Corrects long-term difference between desired and actual velocity to a target acceleration

Name: PSC_VELXY_D
Description: Velocity (horizontal) D gain.  Corrects short-term changes in velocity

Name: PSC_VELXY_IMAX
Description: Velocity (horizontal) integrator maximum.  Constrains the target acceleration that the I gain will output

Name: PSC_VELXY_FLTE
Description: Velocity (horizontal) input filter.  This filter (in Hz) is applied to the input for P and I terms

Name: PSC_VELXY_FLTD
Description: Velocity (horizontal) input filter.  This filter (in Hz) is applied to the input for D term

Name: PSC_VELXY_FF
Description: Velocity (horizontal) feed forward gain.  Converts the difference between desired velocity to a target acceleration

Name: PSC_ANGLE_MAX
Description: Maximum lean angle autopilot can request.  Set to zero to use ANGLE_MAX parameter value

Name: PSC_JERK_XY
Description: Jerk limit of the horizontal kinematic path generation used to determine how quickly the aircraft varies the acceleration target

Name: PSC_JERK_Z
Description: Jerk limit of the vertical kinematic path generation used to determine how quickly the aircraft varies the acceleration target

Name: RALLY_TOTAL
Description: Number of rally points currently loaded

Name: RALLY_LIMIT_KM
Description: Maximum distance to rally point. If the closest rally point is more than this number of kilometers from the current position and the home location is closer than any of the rally points from the current position then do RTL to home rather than to the closest rally point. This prevents a leftover rally point from a different airfield being used accidentally. If this is set to 0 then the closest rally point is always used.

Name: RALLY_INCL_HOME
Description: Controls if Home is included as a Rally point (i.e. as a safe landing place) for RTL

Name: RC_OVERRIDE_TIME
Description: Timeout after which RC overrides will no longer be used, and RC input will resume, 0 will disable RC overrides, -1 will never timeout, and continue using overrides until they are disabled

Name: RC_OPTIONS
Description: RC input options

Name: RC_PROTOCOLS
Description: Bitmask of enabled RC protocols. Allows narrowing the protocol detection to only specific types of RC receivers which can avoid issues with incorrect detection. Set to 1 to enable all protocols.

Name: RC10_MIN
Description: RC minimum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

Name: RC10_TRIM
Description: RC trim (neutral) PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

Name: RC10_MAX
Description: RC maximum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

Name: RC10_REVERSED
Description: Reverse channel input. Set to 0 for normal operation. Set to 1 to reverse this input channel.

Name: RC10_DZ
Description: PWM dead zone in microseconds around trim or bottom

Name: RC10_OPTION
Description: Function assigned to this RC channel

Description: RC minimum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

Name: RC2_TRIM
Description: RC trim (neutral) PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

Name: RC2_MAX
Description: RC maximum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

Name: RC2_REVERSED
Description: Reverse channel input. Set to 0 for normal operation. Set to 1 to reverse this input channel.

Name: RC2_DZ
Description: PWM dead zone in microseconds around trim or bottom

Name: RC2_OPTION
Description: Function assigned to this RC channel

Name: RCMAP_ROLL
Description: Roll channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Roll is normally on channel 1, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter.  Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

Name: RCMAP_PITCH
Description: Pitch channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Pitch is normally on channel 2, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter.  Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

Name: RCMAP_THROTTLE
Description: Throttle channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Throttle is normally on channel 3, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter. Warning APM 2.X: Changing the throttle channel could produce unexpected fail-safe results if connection between receiver and on-board PPM Encoder is lost. Disabling on-board PPM Encoder is recommended.  Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

Name: RCMAP_YAW
Description: Yaw channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Yaw (also known as rudder) is normally on channel 4, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter.  Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

Name: RELAY_PIN
Description: Digital pin number for first relay control. This is the pin used for camera control.

Name: RELAY_PIN2
Description: Digital pin number for 2nd relay control.

Name: RELAY_PIN3
Description: Digital pin number for 3rd relay control.

Name: RELAY_PIN4
Description: Digital pin number for 4th relay control.

Name: RELAY_DEFAULT
Description: The state of the relay on boot.

Name: RELAY_PIN5
Description: Digital pin number for 5th relay control.

Name: RELAY_PIN6
Description: Digital pin number for 6th relay control.

Name: RNGFND1_TYPE
Description: Type of connected rangefinder

Name: RNGFND1_PIN
Description: Analog or PWM input pin that rangefinder is connected to. Airspeed ports can be used for Analog input, AUXOUT can be used for PWM input. When using analog pin 103, the maximum value of the input in 3.3V.

Name: RNGFND1_SCALING
Description: Scaling factor between rangefinder reading and distance. For the linear and inverted functions this is in meters per volt. For the hyperbolic function the units are meterVolts. For Maxbotix serial sonar this is unit conversion to meters.

Name: RNGFND1_OFFSET
Description: Offset in volts for zero distance for analog rangefinders. Offset added to distance in centimeters for PWM lidars

Name: RNGFND1_FUNCTION
Description: Control over what function is used to calculate distance. For a linear function, the distance is (voltage-offset)*scaling. For a inverted function the distance is (offset-voltage)*scaling. For a hyperbolic function the distance is scaling/(voltage-offset). The functions return the distance in meters.

Name: RNGFND1_MIN_CM
Description: Minimum distance in centimeters that rangefinder can reliably read

Name: RNGFND1_MAX_CM
Description: Maximum distance in centimeters that rangefinder can reliably read

Name: RNGFND1_STOP_PIN
Description: Digital pin that enables/disables rangefinder measurement for the pwm rangefinder. A value of -1 means no pin. If this is set, then the pin is set to 1 to enable the rangefinder and set to 0 to disable it. This is used to enable powersaving when out of range.

Name: RNGFND1_RMETRIC
Description: This parameter sets whether an analog rangefinder is ratiometric. Most analog rangefinders are ratiometric, meaning that their output voltage is influenced by the supply voltage. Some analog rangefinders (such as the SF/02) have their own internal voltage regulators so they are not ratiometric.

Name: RNGFND1_PWRRNG
Description: This parameter sets the estimated terrain distance in meters above which the sensor will be put into a power saving mode (if available). A value of zero means power saving is not enabled

Name: RNGFND1_GNDCLEAR
Description: This parameter sets the expected range measurement(in cm) that the range finder should return when the vehicle is on the ground.

Name: RNGFND1_ADDR
Description: This sets the bus address of the sensor, where applicable. Used for the I2C and DroneCAN sensors to allow for multiple sensors on different addresses.

Name: RNGFND1_POS_X
Description: X position of the rangefinder in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Use the zero range datum point if supplied.

Name: RNGFND1_POS_Y
Description: Y position of the rangefinder in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Use the zero range datum point if supplied.

Name: RNGFND1_POS_Z
Description: Z position of the rangefinder in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Use the zero range datum point if supplied.

Name: RNGFND1_ORIENT
Description: Orientation of rangefinder

Name: RNGFND1_WSP_MAVG
Description: Sets the number of historic range results to use for calculating the current range result. When MAVG is greater than 1, the current range result will be the current measured value averaged with the N-1 previous results

Name: RNGFND1_WSP_MEDF
Description: Sets the window size for the real-time median filter. When MEDF is greater than 0 the median filter is active

Name: RNGFND1_WSP_FRQ
Description: Sets the repetition frequency of the ranging operation in Hertz. Upon entering the desired frequency the system will calculate the nearest frequency that it can handle according to the resolution of internal timers.

Name: RNGFND1_WSP_AVG
Description: Sets the number of pulses to be used in multi-pulse averaging mode. In this mode, a sequence of rapid fire ranges are taken and then averaged to improve the accuracy of the measurement

Name: RNGFND1_WSP_THR
Description: Sets the system sensitivity. Larger values of THR represent higher sensitivity. The system may limit the maximum value of THR to prevent excessive false alarm rates based on settings made at the factory. Set to -1 for automatic threshold adjustments

Name: RNGFND1_WSP_BAUD
Description: Desired baud rate

Name: RNGFND1_RECV_ID
Description: The receive ID of the CAN frames. A value of zero means all IDs are accepted.

Name: RNGFND1_SNR_MIN
Description: Minimum signal strength (SNR) to accept distance

Description: This parameter sets the estimated terrain distance in meters above which the sensor will be put into a power saving mode (if available). A value of zero means power saving is not enabled

Name: RNGFND6_GNDCLEAR
Description: This parameter sets the expected range measurement(in cm) that the range finder should return when the vehicle is on the ground.

Name: RNGFND6_ADDR
Description: This sets the bus address of the sensor, where applicable. Used for the I2C and DroneCAN sensors to allow for multiple sensors on different addresses.

Name: RNGFND6_POS_X
Description: X position of the rangefinder in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Use the zero range datum point if supplied.

Name: RNGFND6_POS_Y
Description: Y position of the rangefinder in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Use the zero range datum point if supplied.

Name: RNGFND6_POS_Z
Description: Z position of the rangefinder in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Use the zero range datum point if supplied.

Name: RNGFND6_ORIENT
Description: Orientation of rangefinder

Name: RNGFND6_WSP_MAVG
Description: Sets the number of historic range results to use for calculating the current range result. When MAVG is greater than 1, the current range result will be the current measured value averaged with the N-1 previous results

Name: RNGFND6_WSP_MEDF
Description: Sets the window size for the real-time median filter. When MEDF is greater than 0 the median filter is active

Name: RNGFND6_WSP_FRQ
Description: Sets the repetition frequency of the ranging operation in Hertz. Upon entering the desired frequency the system will calculate the nearest frequency that it can handle according to the resolution of internal timers.

Name: RNGFND6_WSP_AVG
Description: Sets the number of pulses to be used in multi-pulse averaging mode. In this mode, a sequence of rapid fire ranges are taken and then averaged to improve the accuracy of the measurement

Name: RNGFND6_WSP_THR
Description: Sets the system sensitivity. Larger values of THR represent higher sensitivity. The system may limit the maximum value of THR to prevent excessive false alarm rates based on settings made at the factory. Set to -1 for automatic threshold adjustments

Name: RNGFND6_WSP_BAUD
Description: Desired baud rate

Name: RNGFND6_RECV_ID
Description: The receive ID of the CAN frames. A value of zero means all IDs are accepted.

Name: RNGFND6_SNR_MIN
Description: Minimum signal strength (SNR) to accept distance

Name: RNGFND7_TYPE
Description: Type of connected rangefinder

Name: RNGFND7_PIN
Description: Analog or PWM input pin that rangefinder is connected to. Airspeed ports can be used for Analog input, AUXOUT can be used for PWM input. When using analog pin 103, the maximum value of the input in 3.3V.

Name: RNGFND7_SCALING
Description: Scaling factor between rangefinder reading and distance. For the linear and inverted functions this is in meters per volt. For the hyperbolic function the units are meterVolts. For Maxbotix serial sonar this is unit conversion to meters.

Name: RNGFND7_OFFSET
Description: Offset in volts for zero distance for analog rangefinders. Offset added to distance in centimeters for PWM lidars

Name: RNGFND7_FUNCTION
Description: Control over what function is used to calculate distance. For a linear function, the distance is (voltage-offset)*scaling. For a inverted function the distance is (offset-voltage)*scaling. For a hyperbolic function the distance is scaling/(voltage-offset). The functions return the distance in meters.

Name: RNGFND7_MIN_CM
Description: Minimum distance in centimeters that rangefinder can reliably read

Name: RNGFND7_MAX_CM
Description: Maximum distance in centimeters that rangefinder can reliably read

Name: RNGFND7_STOP_PIN
Description: Digital pin that enables/disables rangefinder measurement for the pwm rangefinder. A value of -1 means no pin. If this is set, then the pin is set to 1 to enable the rangefinder and set to 0 to disable it. This is used to enable powersaving when out of range.

Name: RNGFND7_RMETRIC
Description: This parameter sets whether an analog rangefinder is ratiometric. Most analog rangefinders are ratiometric, meaning that their output voltage is influenced by the supply voltage. Some analog rangefinders (such as the SF/02) have their own internal voltage regulators so they are not ratiometric.

Name: RPM1_TYPE
Description: What type of RPM sensor is connected

Name: RPM1_SCALING
Description: Scaling factor between sensor reading and RPM.

Name: RPM1_MAX
Description: Maximum RPM to report. Only used on type = PWM.

Name: RPM1_MIN
Description: Minimum RPM to report. Only used on type = PWM.

Name: RPM1_MIN_QUAL
Description: Minimum data quality to be used

Name: RPM1_PIN
Description: Which pin to use. Only used on type = PWM.

Name: RPM1_ESC_MASK
Description: Mask of channels which support ESC rpm telemetry. RPM telemetry of the selected channels will be averaged

Name: RPM2_TYPE
Description: What type of RPM sensor is connected

Name: RPM2_SCALING
Description: Scaling factor between sensor reading and RPM.

Name: RPM2_MAX
Description: Maximum RPM to report. Only used on type = PWM.

Name: RPM2_MIN
Description: Minimum RPM to report. Only used on type = PWM.

Name: RPM2_MIN_QUAL
Description: Minimum data quality to be used

Name: RPM2_PIN
Description: Which pin to use. Only used on type = PWM.

Name: RPM2_ESC_MASK
Description: Mask of channels which support ESC rpm telemetry. RPM telemetry of the selected channels will be averaged

Name: RSSI_TYPE
Description: Radio Receiver RSSI type. If your radio receiver supports RSSI of some kind, set it here, then set its associated RSSI_XXXXX parameters, if any.

Name: RSSI_ANA_PIN
Description: Pin used to read the RSSI voltage or PWM value

Name: RSSI_PIN_LOW
Description: RSSI pin's voltage received on the RSSI_ANA_PIN when the signal strength is the weakest. Some radio receivers put out inverted values so this value may be higher than RSSI_PIN_HIGH. When using pin 103, the maximum value of the parameter is 3.3V.

Name: RSSI_PIN_HIGH
Description: RSSI pin's voltage received on the RSSI_ANA_PIN when the signal strength is the strongest. Some radio receivers put out inverted values so this value may be lower than RSSI_PIN_LOW. When using pin 103, the maximum value of the parameter is 3.3V.

Name: RSSI_CHANNEL
Description: The channel number where RSSI will be output by the radio receiver (5 and above).

Name: RSSI_CHAN_LOW
Description: PWM value that the radio receiver will put on the RSSI_CHANNEL or RSSI_ANA_PIN when the signal strength is the weakest. Some radio receivers output inverted values so this value may be lower than RSSI_CHAN_HIGH

Name: RSSI_CHAN_HIGH
Description: PWM value that the radio receiver will put on the RSSI_CHANNEL or RSSI_ANA_PIN when the signal strength is the strongest. Some radio receivers output inverted values so this value may be higher than RSSI_CHAN_LOW

Name: SCHED_DEBUG
Description: Set to non-zero to enable scheduler debug messages. When set to show "Slips" the scheduler will display a message whenever a scheduled task is delayed due to too much CPU load. When set to ShowOverruns the scheduled will display a message whenever a task takes longer than the limit promised in the task table.

Name: SCHED_LOOP_RATE
Description: This controls the rate of the main control loop in Hz. This should only be changed by developers. This only takes effect on restart. Values over 400 are considered highly experimental.

Name: SCHED_OPTIONS
Description: This controls optional aspects of the scheduler.

Name: SCR_ENABLE
Description: Controls if scripting is enabled

Name: SCR_VM_I_COUNT
Description: The number virtual machine instructions that can be run before considering a script to have taken an excessive amount of time

Name: SCR_HEAP_SIZE
Description: Amount of memory available for scripting

Name: SCR_DEBUG_OPTS
Description: Debugging options

Name: SCR_USER1
Description: General purpose user variable input for scripts

Name: SCR_USER2
Description: General purpose user variable input for scripts

Name: SCR_USER3
Description: General purpose user variable input for scripts

Name: SCR_USER4
Description: General purpose user variable input for scripts

Name: SCR_USER5
Description: General purpose user variable input for scripts

Name: SCR_USER6
Description: General purpose user variable input for scripts

Name: SCR_DIR_DISABLE
Description: This will stop scripts being loaded from the given locations

Name: SERIAL0_BAUD
Description: The baud rate used on the USB console. Most stm32-based boards can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

Name: SERIAL0_PROTOCOL
Description: Control what protocol to use on the console.

Name: SERIAL1_PROTOCOL
Description: Control what protocol to use on the Telem1 port. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

Name: SERIAL1_BAUD
Description: The baud rate used on the Telem1 port. Most stm32-based boards can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

Name: SERIAL2_PROTOCOL
Description: Control what protocol to use on the Telem2 port. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

Name: SERIAL2_BAUD
Description: The baud rate of the Telem2 port. Most stm32-based boards can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

Name: SERIAL3_PROTOCOL
Description: Control what protocol Serial 3 (GPS) should be used for. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

Name: SERIAL3_BAUD
Description: The baud rate used for the Serial 3 (GPS). Most stm32-based boards can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

Name: SERIAL4_PROTOCOL
Description: Control what protocol Serial4 port should be used for. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

Name: SERIAL4_BAUD
Description: The baud rate used for Serial4. Most stm32-based boards can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

Name: SERIAL5_PROTOCOL
Description: Control what protocol Serial5 port should be used for. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

Name: SERIAL5_BAUD
Description: The baud rate used for Serial5. Most stm32-based boards can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

Name: SERIAL6_PROTOCOL
Description: Control what protocol Serial6 port should be used for. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

Name: SERIAL6_BAUD
Description: The baud rate used for Serial6. Most stm32-based boards can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

Name: SERIAL1_OPTIONS
Description: Control over UART options. The InvertRX option controls invert of the receive pin. The InvertTX option controls invert of the transmit pin. The HalfDuplex option controls half-duplex (onewire) mode, where both transmit and receive is done on the transmit wire. The Swap option allows the RX and TX pins to be swapped on STM32F7 based boards.

Name: SERIAL2_OPTIONS
Description: Control over UART options. The InvertRX option controls invert of the receive pin. The InvertTX option controls invert of the transmit pin. The HalfDuplex option controls half-duplex (onewire) mode, where both transmit and receive is done on the transmit wire.

Name: SERIAL3_OPTIONS
Description: Control over UART options. The InvertRX option controls invert of the receive pin. The InvertTX option controls invert of the transmit pin. The HalfDuplex option controls half-duplex (onewire) mode, where both transmit and receive is done on the transmit wire.

Name: SERIAL4_OPTIONS
Description: Control over UART options. The InvertRX option controls invert of the receive pin. The InvertTX option controls invert of the transmit pin. The HalfDuplex option controls half-duplex (onewire) mode, where both transmit and receive is done on the transmit wire.

Name: SERIAL5_OPTIONS
Description: Control over UART options. The InvertRX option controls invert of the receive pin. The InvertTX option controls invert of the transmit pin. The HalfDuplex option controls half-duplex (onewire) mode, where both transmit and receive is done on the transmit wire.

Name: SERIAL6_OPTIONS
Description: Control over UART options. The InvertRX option controls invert of the receive pin. The InvertTX option controls invert of the transmit pin. The HalfDuplex option controls half-duplex (onewire) mode, where both transmit and receive is done on the transmit wire.

Name: SERIAL_PASS1
Description: This sets one side of pass-through between two serial ports. Once both sides are set then all data received on either port will be passed to the other port

Name: SERIAL_PASS2
Description: This sets one side of pass-through between two serial ports. Once both sides are set then all data received on either port will be passed to the other port

Name: SERIAL_PASSTIMO
Description: This sets a timeout for serial pass-through in seconds. When the pass-through is enabled by setting the SERIAL_PASS1 and SERIAL_PASS2 parameters then it remains in effect until no data comes from the first port for SERIAL_PASSTIMO seconds. This allows the port to revent to its normal usage (such as MAVLink connection to a GCS) when it is no longer needed. A value of 0 means no timeout.

Name: SERIAL7_PROTOCOL
Description: Control what protocol Serial7 port should be used for. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

Name: SERIAL7_BAUD
Description: The baud rate used for Serial7. Most stm32-based boards can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

Name: SERIAL7_OPTIONS
Description: Control over UART options. The InvertRX option controls invert of the receive pin. The InvertTX option controls invert of the transmit pin. The HalfDuplex option controls half-duplex (onewire) mode, where both transmit and receive is done on the transmit wire.

Name: SERIAL8_PROTOCOL
Description: Control what protocol Serial8 port should be used for. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

Name: SERIAL8_BAUD
Description: The baud rate used for Serial8. Most stm32-based boards can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

Name: SERIAL8_OPTIONS
Description: Control over UART options. The InvertRX option controls invert of the receive pin. The InvertTX option controls invert of the transmit pin. The HalfDuplex option controls half-duplex (onewire) mode, where both transmit and receive is done on the transmit wire.

Name: SERIAL9_PROTOCOL
Description: Control what protocol Serial9 port should be used for. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

Name: SERIAL9_BAUD
Description: The baud rate used for Serial8. Most stm32-based boards can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

Name: SERIAL9_OPTIONS
Description: Control over UART options. The InvertRX option controls invert of the receive pin. The InvertTX option controls invert of the transmit pin. The HalfDuplex option controls half-duplex (onewire) mode, where both transmit and receive is done on the transmit wire.

Name: SERVO_RATE
Description: This sets the default output rate in Hz for all outputs.

Name: SERVO_DSHOT_RATE
Description: This sets the DShot output rate for all outputs as a multiple of the loop rate. 0 sets the output rate to be fixed at 1Khz for low loop rates. This value should never be set below 500Hz.

Name: SERVO_DSHOT_ESC
Description: This sets the DShot ESC type for all outputs. The ESC type affects the range of DShot commands available. None means that no dshot commands will be executed.

Name: SERVO_GPIO_MASK
Description: This sets a bitmask of outputs which will be available as GPIOs. Any auxillary output with either the function set to -1 or with the corresponding bit set in this mask will be available for use as a GPIO pin

Name: SERVO10_MIN
Description: minimum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

Name: SERVO10_MAX
Description: maximum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

Name: SERVO10_TRIM
Description: Trim PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

Name: SERVO10_REVERSED
Description: Reverse servo operation. Set to 0 for normal operation. Set to 1 to reverse this output channel.

Name: SERVO10_FUNCTION
Description: Function assigned to this servo. Setting this to Disabled(0) will setup this output for control by auto missions or MAVLink servo set commands. any other value will enable the corresponding function
